setting.name: EnergyWarningThreshold

setting.description: Setting this to ON will enable a prompt when you attempt to upgrade technologies from the tech menu. Setting this to OFF will disable that prompt.

setting.name: PauseGameEnteringEscMenu
setting.display_name: Pause Game When Opening Esc Menu

setting.name: DisableParallelFactionProcessing
setting.description:
Only matters in single-player, or the host in multiplayer. Parallel Faction Processing (PFP) lets the factions in the game be substantially smarter and faster in how they react to things, and is most notable at higher simulation speeds (5x, etc).
On a lot of gaming-style computers, not only does the PFP function make factions and the AI smarter, but it actually can improve performance. We highly recommend you play with this on if your performance in the game is looking suitable.
If you are on a computer with very few cores, then we provide the option here to disable PFP so that the processing is time-sliced. This makes the AI and factions notably slower to react, and the higher the simulation speed you choose, the worse it will get.
If you play at 5x sim speed and have PFP off, we don't consider that a valid way to beat difficulty 10 AIs -- they're half-braindead, so it's not really a fair fight. With PFP on, or at 1x sim speed, you'll see the true fury of the maximum difficulties.

setting.name: EnablePerformanceLogging
setting.description: Turning this on may hurt performance a bit, but not hugely so in most cases. It lets you then see a lot of information about how the game is spending its CPU time by right-clicking the timer in the bottom left of the main game view. Off by default, as it has no other purpose than that.

setting.description: Automatically build factories along with Command Stations.

setting.name: AutoBuildWatchmenFrigates
setting.description: Automatically build Watchman Frigates wherever possible.

setting.name: AutoBuildAssaultFrigates

setting.name: AutoBuildEngineers
setting.description: Automatically build Engineers for Command Stations.

setting.description: Set engineers to automatically do work. This is super useful and probably should not be turned off -- you can still give engineers orders that will override this!

setting.name: AutoKite

setting.name: ShowShipAndPlanetDetailModeByDefault

setting.description: Normally ships and planets show a very condensed amount of information about themselves in their tooltips. However, you can hold a key (shown at the bottom of those tooltips) to make them show a little more info or a whole lot more info. If you prefer to see the complete info by default, then you can enable this option.

setting.name: ShowWeaponActivityDetails

setting.name: ShowPlanetNamesAboveWormholesByDefault

setting.name: ShipIconScale

setting.name: VoiceRoutineVolume

setting.name: AlertVolume

setting.name: AllowFunnyVoiceClips
setting.description: Humor is subjective, and for some folks can even be a mood-killer in a game like this about galactic stakes. Some of the AI voice taunts err on the possibly-mood-breaking side, and those are disabled by default. If you're in a lighter mood and would like to have those included, feel free to turn this on.

setting.name: MusicPlayClassicTracks

setting.description: There is over FOUR AND A HALF HOURS of lightly-remastered music available here, almost all the tracks from the first game and its six expansions, just skipping some we didn't feel were up to snuff. This is on by default since people weren't aware usually of this option, and were just hearing the new tracks for this game, which could get repetitive. If you came from the first game though, and want to just hear the new stuff, you can turn this off.

setting.name: WindowWidth
setting.description: Width of the screen when in windowed mode ONLY. Can be any number between 600 and 9000. Defaults to 1000. You probably want it larger.

setting.name: WindowHeight
setting.description: Height of the screen when in windowed mode ONLY. Can be any number between 400 and 7000. Defaults to 600. You probably want it larger.

setting.name: UseFullscreen

setting.name: FullscreenResolution
setting.description: The following options are available for fullscreen resolutions, based on a combination of what your monitor reports as possible and what are common resolutions.

setting.name: DisplaySaturation
setting.description: The entire game will become more or less saturated based on your choice here, which can have an effect on how 'colorful' or 'serious' the game feels. Tune to taste between 0.1 and 1; the new default is 0.8. Hit save to see how the new saturation looks.

setting.description: The entire game will become more or less bright based on your choice here, which can affect the mood of the game OR compensate for your monitor being brighter or darker than average. Tune to taste between 0.6 and 2, with the default being 1. Hit save to see how the new brightness looks.

setting.name: SkipDrawingShipModels
setting.description: The game is completely playable in an icon-only format, if you wish to do so. For ultra low-specs machines, this is a way to take most of the load off the GPU.

setting.name: DisableShots
setting.display_name: Do not show Shot visual effects
setting.description: Do not show any visual effects for shots. Can slightly improve performance, or make the screen look less busy

setting.name: DisableExplosions
setting.display_name: Do not show Explosion visual effects
setting.description: Do not show any visual effects for Explosions. Can slightly improve performance, or make the screen look less busy

setting.name: FramerateType
setting.description:
Please note that this is NOT the same as setting a refresh rate on your monitor. Mostly. <size=9> If you set VSync or Half-VSync, then indeed it will limit to those and you will likely see terrible performance. Using vsync is a really bad idea, in that it really causes issues with variable-length frames, and will make your game choppier.
Assuming that you are using any other options in this list, it is telling the game to 'try to run at about that framerate.' That won't actually mean the game runs at that framerate, but it will mean that the game tries to not run on average MORE than that framerate. For one example, you don't need the game running at 300fps for no reason and having your GPU fan going nuts. On the other hand, if the game gets choppy when above 60fps for you on an older machine, you might want to cap it at 60fps. If you wish to set this to match your monitor refresh rate, that is fine, but please bear in mind that the non-vsync versions of this are very very much 'weak suggestions for maximum framerate,' and not any sort of hard limiter. <size=10> Looking for excellent technology to eliminate screen tearing without eliminating game performance? The things to look into are GSync and FreeSync.

setting.name: ZoomInMovesTowardsCursor
setting.description:
When you zoom in, the screen will focus on your mouse cursor. This is a cool innovation in various RTS games (and productivity software, too) from the last 10 years.
But some folks prefer that the camera instead zoom straight in regardless of where their mouse cursor is, hence this option.

setting.name: InvertMouseZoom
setting.description: Normally when you spin the mouse wheel forward, you zoom closer; backwards zooms you away. This lets you flip that functionality. OR, in the case that your hardware or OS is inverted for whatever reason, this lets you correct it to work like everyone else.

setting.name: CameraRotationAndTiltSensitivity
setting.description: When you are holding down the buttons that let you tilt and rotate the camera, the movements of your mouse will do those actions based on the sensitivity defined here.

setting.name: CameraMain_CameraTypeClass
setting.description: Highly recommended that you leave this on the default. However, it's possible for modders (and us devs) to add completely custom cameras in place with their own controls, movement style, etc.

setting.name: CameraMain_PanSpeedMultiplierFast
setting.description: If you are holding down the button that speeds up camera movements, then it will multiply camera panning by this amount.

setting.name: CameraMain_ZoomSpeedMultiplierFast
setting.description: If you are holding down the button that speeds up camera movements, then it will multiply camera zooming by this amount.

setting.name: CameraMain_RotateSpeedMultiplierFast
setting.description: Not used by the default cameras.

setting.name: CameraMain_SpeedMultiplierSlow
setting.description: If you are holding down the button that slows down camera movements, then it will multiply camera panning by this amount.

setting.name: CameraMain_AllowScreenEdgePanning
setting.description: By default, the screen will pan in the direction of your cursor when you place your cursor at the edge of the screen. However, some folks find this annoying; so you can turn it off.

setting.name: CameraMain_KeyboardMoveSpeed
setting.description: Increases or decreases how fast your camera moves when you use the keyboard keys to pan the camera.

setting.name: CameraMain_MouseEdgeMoveSpeed
setting.description: Increases or decreases how fast your camera moves when you put the mouse at the edge of the screen to pan the camera.~

setting.name: CameraMain_MouseGrabDragSpeed
setting.description: Increases or decreases how fast your camera moves when you have used (typically the middle mouse button) to 'grab' the screen with the mouse and pan the camera.

setting.name: CameraMain_KeyboardRotateSpeed
setting.description: Not used by the default cameras.

setting.name: CameraMain_KeyboardZoomSpeed
setting.description: How fast the camera zooms in and out when you are using the keyboard keys to trigger zoom.

setting.name: CameraMain_MouseZoomSpeed
setting.description: How fast the camera zooms in and out when you are using the mouse wheel to trigger zoom.

setting.name: CameraMain_MovementLerpSpeed
setting.description: Not used by the default cameras.

setting.name: CameraMain_RotationLerpSpeed
setting.description: Not used by the default cameras.

setting.name: CameraMain_ZoomLerpSpeed
setting.description: Not used by the default cameras.

setting.name: CameraMain_IconsDrawOverEverything
setting.description: With this on, which is the default, icons show in front of everything. If you view ships from a side angle, then you'll see icons from BEHIND those ships in front of them. This is consistent with most other strategy games, but may not be to everyone's tastes.

setting.name: CameraMain_IgnoreIconYOffsets
setting.description: With this on, which is the default, icons drop down and show exactly where the ships themselves are. This is very helpful if 'Icons Draw Over Everything' is ON, but with 'Icons Draw Over Everything' set to off it will make many icons actually invisible since they will clip into their own ships.

setting.name: CameraMain_IconsDisappearWhenCameraLowerThan
setting.display_name: Icons Disappear When Camera Lower Than
setting.description: To have an uncluttered view when you zoom far in, you can make it so that all the icons and wormhole names and so forth all disappear once your main camera gets below this height. Default is 200.

setting.name: GalaxyMapShowPlanetNames
setting.description: If this is set, planet names are always visible on the galaxy map. Some people really love this, but it can be overwhelmingly cluttered-feeling to others, so we don't have it on by default.

setting.name: GalaxyMapScaleIconsScale
setting.description: Depending on the size of your monitor, you may prefer the icons on the galaxy map (planets and otherwise) to be larger or smaller. The default is 1.5 since smaller than that was feeling a bit too tiny for anyone not on huge monitors.

setting.name: GalaxyMinimalFogOfWar
setting.description: If this is set, you get complete information of enemy forces on the galaxy map even for Explored planets. This will make the game easier.

setting.name: GalaxyMapTextHidesAt
setting.display_name: Text By Planets Hides At Distance
setting.description: At some point when you zoom out far enough on the galaxy map, things get too crowded with all the little text next to each planet. Lower numbers here make the text disappear sooner, higher numbers make them disappear after you zoom out more.

setting.name: GalaxyMapIconsHideAt
setting.display_name: Icons By Planets Hides At Distance
setting.description: At some point when you zoom out far enough on the galaxy map, things get too crowded with all the little icons for ships/structures next to each planet. Lower numbers here make the icons disappear sooner, higher numbers make them disappear after you zoom out more.

setting.name: GalaxyMap_HexagonIntensity
setting.description: If you would like the background to be more stylized hexagons, then you can turn this up.

setting.name: GalaxyMap_HideHexagons
setting.description: If you would like the background stylized hexagons to disappear, you can turn off this setting.

setting.name: GalaxyMap_BloomIntensity
setting.description: How glowy would you like the galaxy map to appear? More looks more computer-screeny, but can be distracting depending on your contrast settings on your monitor.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_CameraTypeClass
setting.description: Highly recommended that you leave this on the default. However, it's possible for modders (and us devs) to add completely custom cameras in place with their own controls, movement style, etc.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_PanSpeedMultiplierFast
setting.description: If you are holding down the button that speeds up camera movements, then it will multiply camera panning by this amount.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_ZoomSpeedMultiplierFast
setting.description: If you are holding down the button that speeds up camera movements, then it will multiply camera zooming by this amount.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_RotateSpeedMultiplierFast
setting.description: Not used by the galaxy map camera at all.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_SpeedMultiplierSlow
setting.description: If you are holding down the button that slows down camera movements, then it will multiply camera panning by this amount.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_AllowScreenEdgePanning
setting.description: By default, the screen will pan in the direction of your cursor when you place your cursor at the edge of the screen. However, some folks find this annoying; so you can turn it off.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_KeyboardMoveSpeed
setting.description: Increases or decreases how fast your camera moves when you use the keyboard keys to pan the camera.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_MouseEdgeMoveSpeed
setting.description: Increases or decreases how fast your camera moves when you put the mouse at the edge of the screen to pan the camera.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_MouseGrabDragSpeed
setting.description: Increases or decreases how fast your camera moves when you have used (typically the middle mouse button) to 'grab' the screen with the mouse and pan the camera.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_KeyboardRotateSpeed
setting.description: Not used by the galaxy map camera at all.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_KeyboardZoomSpeed
setting.description: How fast the camera zooms in and out when you are using the keyboard keys to trigger zoom.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_MouseZoomSpeed
setting.description: How fast the camera zooms in and out when you are using the mouse wheel to trigger zoom.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_MovementLerpSpeed
setting.description: Not used by the default cameras.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_RotationLerpSpeed
setting.description: Not used by the galaxy map camera at all.

setting.name: CameraGalaxy_ZoomLerpSpeed
setting.description: Not used by the default cameras.

setting.name: NetworkPort
setting.description: This is the networking 'port' that one player is hosting on and that other players will try to connect to.

setting.name: LastIPTriedToConnectTo
setting.display_name: Last IP Tried To Connect To

setting.name: HackingDebug
setting.description: Log details about hacking responses in the ArcenDebugLog. Intended for developer use.

setting.name: AllegianceDebug
setting.description: Log details which factions are allied with which other factions. Intended for developer use

setting.name: ThreatDebug
setting.description: Log details about when AI ships turn to threat. Works like tracing, but making tracing do this would be obnoxious.

setting.name: EnableReinforcementLogging
setting.description: Reinforcements are ships/structures that the AI gets to each of its planets based on budgets that accumulate over time. If you think something is amiss, you can enable this and send us the result to look at.

setting.name: ShowEntityIDInHovertext
setting.description: For debugging purposes only, but lets you see the globally unique ID for any entity you hover over.

setting.name: DebugNonPlayable_SuppressNormalMultithreading
setting.description: For debugging purposes only, this makes everything run on a single thread (at least in terms of the simulation). Owwwww. This is useful for testing bugs or doing certain types of performance profiling, but that's it.

setting.name: Debug_DrawAllRadiiAtAllTimes
setting.display_name: Draw All Radii At All Times
setting.description: Shows a little circle around each ship, shot, etc. Only for debugging.

setting.name: Debug_DrawTrueLocationOfShotsInsteadOfLerps
setting.display_name: Draw True Location Of Shots Instead Of Lerps
setting.description: This game is complicated. The underlying simulation runs at one coarse framerate on multiple threads, and what you're shown visually is an interpolated visualization of that. If you suspect something is going on with the interpolation, then you can enable this and you'll see shots moving around in a jumpy fashion between their sim-based actual locations.

setting.name: Debug_DrawTrueLocationOfSquadsInsteadOfLerps
setting.display_name: Draw True Location Of Squads Instead Of Lerps
setting.description: Same notes for the shot lerps, above. But this time it will show the true location of the ships/squads in a jerky fashion matching the underlying sim. Fun note: 'lerp' means 'linear interpolation.'

setting.name: Debug_DrawShotDebuggingData
setting.description: For each shot, this draws a ton of little debugging lines showing where it's heading, where the sim thinks it is, where the vis layer thinks it was, etc, etc.

setting.name: Debug_TargettingDebugShipID
setting.display_name: Show debug log for targeting for this unit
setting.description: For debug purposes, this will log a bunch of targeting data. Development only, requires source editing

setting.name: Debug_Tooltip
setting.display_name: Show debug data in unit tooltips
setting.description: Shows extensive debug-level per-unit data in tooltip.

setting.name: Debug_IncomingShotTooltip
setting.display_name: Show incoming-shot debug data in unit tooltips
setting.description: When this is on, show the information about any incoming shots headed to a target.

setting.name: Debug_WriteSerializationLogs
setting.description:
When saving a game, write WorldSerialization.txt, and when loading it write WorldDeserialization.txt -- both in the PlayerData folder. The only real reason to turn this on is if a savegame won't load for some reason; this lets us do a diff of the two files and figure out where they are diverging.
Note that this won't help with an existing broken savegame. This will only help if you have it turned on prior to creating a savegame you expect to be broken. This is basically a way for us to test the savegame creation and load process, which otherwise can be incredibly opaque and take a lot of time to hunt down.

setting.name: Debug_WriteMapgenLog
setting.description: When generating a new map in the lobby, write MapGen.txt in the PlayerData folder. The only real reason to turn this on is if mapgen isn't really doing what you expect for some reason, or you just want some detailed insight into what is happening and in what order.

setting.name: Debug_WriteFleetIDInTooltips
setting.description: If something seems off with the fleets, such as a planet having more units than reported, then this is a way to see if it's a matter of the fleets being improperly handled.

setting.name: Debug_WriteCounterattackInfoInPlanetTooltips
setting.display_name: Write Counterattack Info In Planet Tooltips
setting.description: If something seems off with the fleets, such as a planet having more units than reported, then this is a way to see if it's a matter of the fleets being improperly handled.

setting.name: Debug_WriteAIBudgetInfoInPlanetTooltips
setting.display_name: Write AI Budget Info In Planet Tooltips
setting.description: If something seems off with the planet strengths and reinforcements, then this is a way to see what is going on under the hood.

setting.name: Debug_WriteFleetCenterpieceRepairsInLog
setting.display_name: Write Fleet Centerpiece Repairs In Log
setting.description: Quite often the game needs to re-link the centerpieces of fleets, and it might be useful to see what is happening there under the hood in some limited cases. For the most part this is all just happening as expected, though, so we don't need to clutter up the debug log with this info. If something seems awry, we can turn this on to check it out more.

setting.name: Debug_WriteLobbySetupChangesToLog
setting.display_name: Write Lobby Setup Changes To Log
setting.description: If something strange is going on with the lobby, in multiplayer or otherwise, this is a way for the log to have a variety of data sent about what changes are being requested, and when.

setting.name: Debug_ShowDebugDetailsButtonInLobby
setting.display_name: Show Debug Details Button In Lobby
setting.description: When enabled, a 'Debug Details' button appears in the lobby, which you can click to have it pop up all the relevant information about the current setup from a very low-level debugging style.

setting.name: Debug_ShowShipCoordinates
setting.description: When enabled, hovering over a ship will tell you it's location in in-game coordinates.

setting.name: Debug_ShowConstructionBlockedReason
setting.display_name: Show reason for blocked construction in tooltip.
setting.description: When enabled, hovering over a ship that is blocked from rebuilding will tell you the reason.

setting.name: Debug_ShowFleetShipLineNumbers
setting.description: When enabled, any ship lines in fleets will show what their underlying unique line numbers are.

setting.name: Debug_ShowLODInfoInShipTooltips
setting.display_name: Show LOD Info In Ship Tooltips
setting.description: When enabled, hovering over a ship will make its tooltip show you info about its number of LODs, its poly count per LOD, at what distance it transfers between LODs, and what its current distance from the camera is.

setting.name: ReduceVisualStimulation
setting.description: Not currently implemented.
